awd_titl_txt: BRIGHT-CS: Building Student Retention through Individuated Guided coHort Training in Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
BRIGHT-CS creates a comprehensive computer science and empowerment model for girls of color in computing. Through deep engagement with select high schools, universities, non-profit and community organizations, BRIGHT-CS builds and assesses the strength of an ecosystem that supports girls of color. It acknowledges the larger national effort to achieve gender equity in computing and is intentional in building effective ecosystems to support that. In the spirit of culturally responsive pedagogies, BRIGHT-CS builds on the premise that girls need their identities to be affirmed coincident with their computing skills being honed. 

The work is centered in two locations, in Arlington, VA and in New York City. The targeted groups of students and schools are selected to engage in educational experiences at the intersection of formal and informal learning. They experience a comprehensive set of experiences that begin with affirming their place in computing as young women and girls. The critical partnerships developed in each location are central to testing the proposed hypothesis that effective ecosystems are required for promoting and fostering the sustained success of girls of color in computing.

por.por_cntn:
The Building Student Retention through Individuated Guided Cohort Training in Computer Science (BRIGHT-CS) project focused on two goals.

Goal 1 – Create a group CS learning experience. The learning experience featured positive peer and near-peer mentors among Black girls interested in CS with an emphasis on 1) empowerment and leadership, 2) comprehensive CS and computational thinking (CT) experiences, and 3) partnerships with schools, colleges and universities, and non-profit community organizations.

Goal 2 – Research the effectiveness of the CS learning experience. The team conducted research on the effectiveness of the program to help promote Black girls’ interest in computing and determine best practices for broadening the participation of other underrepresented student groups.

The project involved 60 girls of color in grades 6-8 from four middle schools in New York City and Arlington, Virginia. Additional partners included educators and school leaders, CS mentors and instructors, and universities. These partners helped to create and deliver a weekly 12-month CS learning experience that included CS programming using culturally responsive materials and summer CS programming at a local university.

For Goal 1 (create the CS learning experience), the program was implemented for 18 months before the COVID pandemic suspended in-person schooling in March of 2020. Prior to school closings across the country, BRIGHT-CS offered in-person, weekly CS programming in three of the four middle schools (one school requested a mentoring-only model). These sessions were led by Black women computer scientists serving as instructors and mentors. Additionally, two-week summer programs were offered in two of the four middle schools (two schools did not run a summer program). Units included computational thinking and problem solving, programming in Scratch, and project-based learning with application and game development. The program pivoted in March 2020 to create digital curricular materials for both educators and students that could be accessed remotely. The curricular materials for educators were designed to foster culturally responsive CS learning experiences for middle school students and tested by BRIGHT-CS participants. The curricular materials and digital programming for students were designed to support in-home CS learning, adapted from BRIGHT-CS materials, and beta-tested with several students.

For Goal 2 (research the CS learning experience), data was collected from 53 BRIGHT-CS girls, 3 parents, 7 community members, 4 school sponsors, 4 principals, 3 program instructors, and 3 summer program instructors at multiple times during the program. Participants and their caretakers actively agreed to participate in research activities. Researchers also gathered data from program documents, computing artifacts, weekly observations of CS after-school programming, and daily observations of CS summer programming. All data were quantified, coded, and triangulated. Results indicated that student interest and motivation were not enough to ensure CS engagement and learning. Even when students were highly interested and motivated to learn CS and prior CS experience (with classes, camps, clubs) before participating in the BRIGHT-CS program, the design and implementation of BRIGHT-CS to provide structural, instructional, and curricular supports were critical to developing independent (versus dependent) student learning behaviors. This, in turn, fully engaged students to learn CS. BRIGHT-CS actively and continuously removed structural, instructional, and curricular barriers that Black girls and other girls of color faced when accessing and learning CS via debrief meetings with instructors and school sponsors, formative data use, and feedback from students to adapt implementation. These adaptations supported students in developing the trusting relationships they needed to embrace making mistakes and iterating through their learning process while keeping the non-negotiable elements of the program the same across sites.

Project videos, workbooks, and other materials are available on the BRIGHT-CS website (https://bright-cs.uncg.edu/). Project outcomes (e.g., white papers, conference presentations, etc.) related to research are under the Research Findings tab. Educator curricular materials (i.e., Common Core Standards aligned units on data science, machine learning, and game development) are available under the Teach Computer Science tab. Student programming units (i.e., artificial intelligence, data science, and software development) are available under the Learn Computer Science tab. Future efforts to expand on BRIGHT-CS will feature micro-credentialing for educators and students.
